66.heading: Terminal Illness.
66.title: Janet & Me : an Illustrated Story of Love and Loss
66.author: Stan Mack.
notes: Summary: Stan Mack follows his eighteen-year relationship with Janet Bode, a lighthearted fling that beat the odds to become an enduring love affair. The only thing they couldn't beat was cancer. As Janet and Stan confront the jagged terrain of cancer, then navigate the twilight of terminal illness, two portraits emerge: of a woman who faced her cancer the same way she lived her life, with guts and charm; and of the man who held her close and shared her struggle.
Format is text with interjected drawings and comics.

notes: Summary: The unopposed incumbent, after looking over the highlights of his term in office, decides to lie through his teeth.

138.author: Catherine Ternaux

notes: Reviews the series La Vache (Stephen Desberg & Johan De Moor).

139.heading: Ternaux, Catherine.
139.title: "Petites Crevettes Roses et Banjo-Girls : le Rédactionnel dans la Presse pour Jeunes Filles"
139.author: Catherine Ternaux
139.appears_in: p. 61-65 in 9e Art : les Cahiers du Musée de la Bande Dessinée, no. 6 (Jan. 2001).
notes: Begins: "Longtemps la presse pour jeunes filles s'est adressée aux Suzette, aux Lisette, aux Capucine et autres Mireille dont elle cherchait avant tout à faire des femmes modèles, de 'bonnes petites femmes'. Le rédactionnel très conventionnel de ces magazines ne variait guère d'un titre à l'autre et évolua dans le temps à la vitesse d'un fer à repasser avant l'invention de la vapeur."

English summary (from p. 150): "Editorials in the Young Girls' Press. The editorial content of periodicals like Lisette, Fillette, Bernadette, Mireille and others was often very conventional and only evolved gradually. Catherine Ternaux has reread the editorials, articles, cooking and sewing sections and, of course, the letters from readers."
